title: Ticket #5972: Starter crash during exit()
description:
A post to the htcondor-users list reports a seg-faulting starter. The problem appears to be due to an attempt to send a ClassAd over a socket inside a global destructor, after the global destructors for some internal ClassAd data structures have already been called.

I can reproduce the crash on linux by having the shadow EXCEPT() immediately after creating its child process for moving the input sandbox. The crash doesn't happen consistently, as there's a race between the starter reaping its child process (and calling EXCEPT() due to the failed transfer) and the starter receiving a SIGTERM from the startd.

Here is the sequence of events in the starter:

  • File transfer of the input sandbox is started (child process created)
  • Network connections to the shadow are closed on the remote side
  • SIGTERM received, starter begins a graceful shutdown
  • With no jobs running, starter calls DC_Exit(), which deletes DaemonCore and then calls exit()
  • Destructor for classad::specialAttrNames is called
  • Destructor for CStarter object is called, which causes the following events
    • Destructor for JICShadow is called
    • Destructor for FileTransfer is called, which tries to cancel the active transfer
    • FileTransfer::abortActiveTransfer() ASSERT()s because daemonCore is NULL
    • The starter's custom exception cleanup function tries to write a log entry and send a ClassAd message to the shadow
    • Sending the ClassAd message seg-faults because it tries to evaluate TargetType, which accesses classad::specialAttrNames, which is already deleted.

A simple fix for this problem would be for the starter to disable its custom exception cleanup routine (set _EXCEPT_Cleanup to NULL) before calling DC_Exit(). A better fix would be do most of the tear-down of CStarter and its member objects before calling DC_Exit(), probably by making the CStarter object not be a global object, but one that's deleted before DC_Exit().
remarks:
2016-Oct-18 16:16:33 by jfrey:
Setting _EXCEPT_Cleanup to NULL in CStarter::StarterExit() does prevent this crash. But we're still blundering through a minefield of potential crashes. The FileTransfer destructor called under exit() still causes an EXCEPT() due to daemonCore being NULL. There are surely other pitfalls waiting for us.

2016-Oct-18 16:39:24 by jfrey:
The original post to htcondor-users was made on October 17, 2016, by Antontio Dorta <adorta@iac.es> with the subject line condor_starter... kernel: NMI watchdog: BUG: soft lockup - CPU stuck for....
